[LEXICON]: Use of archaic or outdated expressions ("Thy," "Thee," "free liver," "holiday" in British sense)
[SYNTAX]: Some sentences are overly complex or wordy (e.g., "Thus and otherwise he filled his scanty purse--that needed filling, for he was quick at its emptying...")
[STRUCTURE]: Minor punctuation inconsistencies in complex sentences (e.g., em dash usage)

[LOGIC]: Abrupt shift from religious leadership discussion to Reynolds' art with no transitional explanation
[STRUCTURE]: Disjointed metaphor about "river of civilisation" not fully explained or integrated
[CLARITY]: Sudden, disconnected final sentence "Many artists remain painters all their lives"
[TRANSITION]: Unclear connection between Reynolds' artistic influences and later discussion of his teaching methods

[SYNTAX]: Complex sentence structure in "If the great artists of Italy had shed light upon his path in one direction, what did he not owe..."
[PUNCTUATION]: Comma splice in "Dr. Johnson himself could only have been inspiring company, even though..."
[PHRASING]: Awkward phrasing in "the man in the street might stare open-mouthed and talk about her brother"

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from Reynolds' weaknesses to modern comparisons ("There is hardly a 'Lion Comique,'...")
[STRUCTURE]: Awkward placement of "as in the twentieth, century" in the Leicester Square sentence
[LOGIC]: Sudden jump from personal critique to broader commentary on historical judgment ("It is far more interesting to see great men as they lived")
